document.docTitle: Nematodes In The Deciduous Forests Of Moldova

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Nematodes In The Deciduous Forests Of Moldova
Buletinul ºtiinþific al Muzeului Naþional de Etnografie ºi Istorie Naturalã a Moldovei

emphasis.docTitle: NEMATODES IN THE DECIDUOUS FORESTS OF MOLDOVA

paragraph.emphasis: Nematodele din pădurile foioase din Moldova.

În diferite tipuri de păduri de foioase ale Moldovei au fost depistate 198 specii din 113 genuri, 55 familii şi 10 ordine. Cea mai mare parte din ele sînt bacterivore, urmate de plante parazite, omnivore, micofagi şi prădători. Nematodele bacterivore şi omnivore predomină constant asupra altor grupe trofice. În pădurile naturale şi protejate se menţine o diversitate înaltă de prădători şi numai aici se întîlnesc specii rare şi endemice din diferite grupe taxonomice. E prezentată lista tuturor speciilor de nematode din pădurile Republicii Moldova.

subSection.paragraph: Nematodes are the most diverse group among invertebrates that inhabit the forest soil and litter and also have high densities. They occupy important positions in soil food chains feeding the primary decomposers (bacteria and fungi) and being consumers (plant feeders, predators and omnivores) [ 3 , 10 , 11 , 13 ].Any change in the habitat that influences their food source or environment will be reflected in species diversity [ 4 ].
The first investigations into the soil nematodes of Moldovan forests started in the Codrii Forest Reserve in the 1960s [ 7 ] and the most detailed research has been done after 1990 [ 5 , 6 , 8 , 9 ].

Samples were collected from litter and from the 0-15 cm layer of soil in five replications during more than ten years. Nematodes were extracted by sieving and decanting standard methods of brass screens and Baermann funnels and fixed in a hot 4% formaldehyde solution. The nematode specimens were identified on mass-slides to species [ 1 , 2 , 7 , 12 ]. To determine the trophic groups the outline for soil ecologists of Yeates, G.W.et al. [ 13 ] has been used.

The nematode communities include 198 species in 113 genera, 55 families and 10 orders. Most of the species are from the orders
Dorylaimida
(52 species), Tylenchida (49 species) and
Rhabditida
(47 species); followed by the
Araeolaimida
(with 13 species),
Chromadorida
,
Enoplida
,
Mononchida
(each with 10 species),
Monhysterida
(with 3 species),
Diplogasteridae
(with 3 species) and
Isolaimida
(with 1 species) orders.
Here is a list of soil nematodes found in deciduous forests in the Republic of Moldova.

paragraph.taxonomicName: Criconemoides lineolatus Maas, Loof & de Grisse 1971

subSection.paragraph:
Most of the nematode species are bacterivores (71), followed by plant feeders (36), omnivores (32), fungivores (27), predators (24) and substrate ingestion (8). Specimens of the bacterivorous genera
Mesorhabditis , Pelodera , Rhabditis , Acrobeles , Acrobeloides , Chiloplacus , Eucephalobus , Stegelletina , Plectus , Aulolaimus , Prismatolaimus , Alaimus
and the fungivores
Aphelenchus , Paraphelenchus , Aphelenchoides
are abundant and frequently presented. In all forests, the ratio of fungivores to bacterivores F/B<1 shows a constant preponderance of bacterivores. The fungivores-bacterivores nematodes make an important component of the litter decomposer community.

The plant feeding group is mainly composed of non-obligatory plant parasites such as ectoparasites and root hair feeders chiefly from the genera
Filenchus
,
Malenchus
and
Tylenchus
. Only endoparasites
( Pratylenchus neglectus , P. penetrans ),
ectoparasites (
Helicotylenchus crenatus
,
H. vulgaris
,
Rotylenchus incultus )
and virus vector species
( Longidorus elongatus , Xiphinema rivesi , Trichodorus primitivus )
could cause some depressions or diseases in forest plants.

Most of the predators from the genera
Tripyla , Tripylina , Clarkus , Anatonchus , Prionchulus , Mylonchulus , Aquatides
and
Nygolaimus
are located in the humiferous soil layer. The large sized omnivorous specimens from the
Mesodorylaimus , Eudorylaimus , Epidorylaimus
and
Thonus
genera are well presented in all the layers of forest soil.

The abundance of nematodes in deciduous forests varies between 1.4· 106 and 2.3· 106 specimens/m 2 depending on the type of forest and well-defined layer of surface litter. The richness of nematode species varies from high value in beech forests (65) to low value in maple-hornbeam and oak forests (34–38).

An astonishingly high species and trophic diversity of soil nematodes is found in different deciduous forests in Moldova. Soil nematode communities include 198 species in 113 genera, 55 families and 10 orders. Most of the nematode species detected so far are bacterivores, followed by plant feeders, omnivores, fungivores, predators and substrate ingestion. In all forests types, bacterivorous and omnivorous nematodes predominate constantly over other trophic groups. A high diversity of predator forms is observed in native and protected forests and only here rare or endemic species of different taxonomic groups may be found. This is why the protection of natural forests is one of the main national tasks.

paragraph.emphasis: A review of 112 species of aphid parasitoids (Hymenoptera Aphidiidae) from Moldova is presented. We stated that most aberrant specimens were found near military objects, chemical factories and from fields on which new chemical preparations against pest insects were tested and they can be used as indicators of environmental pollution.

subSection.paragraph: This paper is dedicated to the memory of Prof. P.I. Nesterov, my Ph.D. leader, whose works on taxonomy of plant parasites and free-living nematodes have been an inspiration to his colleagues everywhere.
Institute of Zoology, Academy of Sciences of Moldova
Recenzent: Valeriu Derjanschi - doctor habilitat, conferenţiar-cercetător.
